folder: Richmond Terrace & Westervelt Avenue, Staten Island, NY
text:
(1)
386 and 396 Richmond Terrace, south side, between Westervelt Avenue and St. Peters Place. No. 386 (left) appears in Bromley's 1917 map as the West Day and Evening School. From 1874 to 1907 it belonged to the Pendleton family. No. 396 belonged to the Wilkinson family according to the real estate maps of 1874 to 1907.
May 2, 1928
P. L. Sperr
(2)
Another view of the two houses, showing, more prominently, No. 396-the Wilkinson house. The view is eastward, the opposite direction from view 1.
May 2, 1928
P. L. Sperr
title: Richmond: Richmond Terrace - Westervelt Avenue

title: Richmond: Richmond Terrace - Westervelt Avenue

folder: Richmond Terrace & Westervelt Avenue, Staten Island, NY
text:
404 Richmond Terrace, adjoining the S. E. corner of Westervelt Avenue, showing the Richmond Knights of Columbus clubhouse. In 1907 it belonged to Geo. J. Greenfield, and from 1874 to 1898 to the Wilkinson family. The house is modeled in the Doric Order of Greek architecture. Across the roof of the house appears the steeple of St. Peters R. C. Church.

May 2, 1928

P. L. Sperr
title: Richmond: Richmond Terrace - Westervelt Avenue

folder: Richmond Terrace & Westervelt Avenue, Staten Island, NY
text:
414 Richmond Terrace, at the S.E. corner of Westervelt Avenue. The mansion was on the Brooks estate in 1874; from 1898 to 1907 it belonged to Jas. Crabtree.

May 2, 1928

P. L. Sperr
title: Richmond: Richmond Terrace - Westervelt Avenue
